Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Conquering land: the evolution of reproductive modes in Narrow-mouth frogs (Anura, Microhylidae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Through an integrative study of DNA sequences and morphological features, including the use of high-resolution computer tomography, we will study the adaptations to terrestrial and arboreal lifestyles in a large group of amphibians - the worldwide-distributed narrow-mouthed frogs (Microhylidae). Microhylids are not entirely restricted to the water for breeding, and many groups have completely abandoned the need of water for reproduction. Examination of anatomical adaptations related to this transition (aquatic to terrestrial breeding) in these frogs can help us understand the evolution of terrestriality in vertebrates as a whole.

Results and data associated with this research will be broadly disseminated for both the scientific community and general public through a variety of outlets (scientific journals, newspapers, internet). Curriculum material will be developed together with the Department of Education the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) as part of the Science Research Mentoring and the Research Experience for Undergrads program at the AMNH, introducing high school and undergrad students to moderns research topics and techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The question of how animals and plants have repeatedly “conquered” terrestrial environments has puzzled biologists for centuries. Invasion of terrestrial ecosystems opened an entire new array of ecological opportunities, and some of the most impressive events of biological diversification have been associated with ancestral colonization of land (i.e. in plants, insects, tetrapods). Amphibians are widely known for a stereotyped dependence on water for reproduction (aquatic eggs and tadpoles). However, several lineages evolved some level of independence from water bodies, culminating in total liberty from an aquatic environment for breeding and development (i.e. terrestrial eggs and no larval phase). Terrestrial breeding have evolved multiple times within Anura and this independence of water has been postulated as a key innovation leading to higher species diversification in many groups of frogs. This project sought to study the evolution of reproductive modes and terrestriality in narrow-mouthed frogs (family Microhylidae) – one of the largest lineages of living amphibians.

We have used a combination of genetic, morphological and behavioral data to infer phylogenetic relationships of microhylids and then trace the pattern of evolution of characters associated with reproductive strategies in these frogs. Genetic data was obtained using novel a combination of modern methods (anchored enrichment of conserved areas of the genome) and traditional (Sanger) sequencing techniques, whereas morphological data was obtained through the examination of museum specimens. This approach allowed us to postulate multiple instances where microhylids shift away from the inferred ancestral state: aquatic eggs that hatch into exotrophic larvae (feeding tadpoles). Endotrophic larvae (non-feeding tadpoles) have evolved multiple times across the family and are present in all members of the Malagasy subfamily Cophylinae.

Frog eggs may show pigmentation (black or brown) or may be unpigmented and previous studies have suggested that unpigmented eggs are usually related to terrestrial endotrophic larvae. Indeed, in narrow-mouthed frogs, unpigmented eggs are present primarily in species with endotrophic larvae, whereas pigmented eggs are present in species with exotrophic larvae (feeding tadpoles). The only exception to this pattern is found in the Malagasy genus Anodonthyla whose endotrophic larvae hatch from pigmented eggs. Several clades have species that are partially terrestrial (eggs attach to plants or are laid in nests), but that still maintain an aquatic larval phase. Complete terrestriality evolved only once, in subfamily Asterophryinae, which is distributed in the Australo-Papuan region. In all Asterophryinae terrestrial eggs develop directly into froglets, the tadpole phase being completely skipped.

The project represents an international collaboration including scientists in Australia, Brazil, India, and the United States. A monograph dealing with the taxonomy and evolution of humming-frogs (genus Chiasmocleis) was published and three new Amazonian species were named in the work. The project contributed to the research training of one PhD student.
